Dispute_Type: Housing allocation and transfer of tenancy rights within a First Nation reserve
Legal_Issue: Does Robin Roberts have a right to remain in the housing unit, and is she entitled to an injunction preventing her eviction?
Evidence_Assessment: Robin failed to provide concrete evidence of efforts to find alternative accommodation; no clear proof of irreparable harm
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (Robin Roberts) did not meet burden for injunctive relief
Credibility_Factor: Lack of documented efforts to secure alternative housing
Legal_Rule: (1) Serious issue to be tried, (2) Irreparable harm if injunction not granted, (3) Balance of convenience favors granting injunction
Grounds_for_Claim: Right to remain based on tenancy dispute and lack of alternative housing
Outcome_on_Merits: No entitlement to remain; must vacate by April 15, 2010
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Not applicable â€“ first instance decision
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Court considered applicant's financial situation in costs decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Claim of having nowhere else to go, lack of documentation on housing search
Applicant_Challenge: Demonstrating irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Court_Result: Injunction denied; seven-day grace period granted with temporary restoration of electricity
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities for interim injunction
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but eviction enforcement was pursued
Evidence_Type: Affidavit or oral testimony regarding housing status and needs
Outcome: Eviction permitted; deadline set for April 15, 2010
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of eviction and continued occupancy
Claimant_Status: Resident seeking to retain housing unit on First Nation reserve
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to demonstrate irreparable harm or justification for priority housing
Jurisdiction: First Nation reserve housing matter under provincial/common law jurisdiction
